metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: Bell OH-58 Kiowa Warrior Development History
The Army formed a task force at Fort Rucker, Alabama on 1 April 1986.
The task force was formed to remedy deficiencies in the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP).
The Army had planned to discontinue the OH-58D during 1988.
The Army had planned to focus on the Light Helicopter Experimental (LHX) during 1988.
Congress approved $138 million to expand the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP).
Congress called for the Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP) to operate with the Apache as a hunter/killer team.
The Army Helicopter Improvement Program (AHIP) would locate targets in the hunter/killer team.
The Apache would destroy targets in the hunter/killer team.
The hunter/killer team was a throwback to the traditional OH-58/AH-1 relationship.
The Secretary of the Army directed that the OH-58D's armament systems be upgraded.
The Secretary's direction was based on experience with Task Force 118's performance.
Task Force 118 operated armed OH-58Ds in the Persian Gulf.
Task Force 118 operated in support of Operation Prime Chance.
The Secretary of the Army directed that the OH-58D be used primarily for scouting.
The Secretary of the Army directed that the OH-58D be used primarily for armed reconnaissance.
The armed aircraft would be known as the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior.
The name "Kiowa Warrior" denoted the OH-58D's new armed configuration.

text:
On 1 April 1986, the Army formed a task force at Fort Rucker, Alabama, to remedy deficiencies in the AHIP. During 1988, the Army had planned to discontinue the OH-58D and focus on the LHX; however, Congress approved $138 million to expand the program, calling for the AHIP to operate with the Apache as a hunter/killer team; the AHIP would locate targets and the Apache would destroy them in a throwback to the traditional OH-58/AH-1 relationship.
The Secretary of the Army directed instead that the aircraft's armament systems be upgraded, based on experience with Task Force 118's performance operating armed OH-58Ds in the Persian Gulf in support of Operation Prime Chance, and that the type be used primarily for scouting and armed reconnaissance. The armed aircraft would be known as the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior, denoting its new armed configuration.
